text: what's up everybody eric here i got a video on why i trade iwm and how i've made over a million bucks in it so i get asked fairly frequently by folks who follow the channel they know i talk about iwm a lot and they're curious about why so this video is going to do a couple things i'm going to walk through why i trade iwm after discussing what it is but more importantly i want to compare it to something like the spy and also the rut which are the most common you know comparisons that people bring up why do i trade iwm over those so first let's start with a quick overview of what iwm is so it's the russell 2000 index so it tracks 000 plus small cap stocks across all different sectors which we'll get into in just a minute but the beauty of it being an index etf is it gives you a lot of flexibility and inherent diversification without having to pay like a mutual fund that sort of thing so let's take a quick look at a comparison so as you can see i have a few metrics that i want to look at when we're comparing iwm to the spy and to the rut so we're going to talk about if it's liquid if there's a dividend if there's diversification and quantify that how efficient the products are and then the underlying so first let's start with spy which

text: want to look at when we're comparing iwm to the spy and to the rut so we're going to talk about if it's liquid if there's a dividend if there's diversification and quantify that how efficient the products are and then the underlying so first let's start with spy which is the s p 500 index etf is it liquid absolutely and we can assess that pretty simply so if we pull up something like spy and we take a look at a few key metrics the first one is the volume over you know 100 million shares traded in a day so plenty of movement you could see that the bid ask spreads are very tight and this is tight because it's after hours so during the market when it's open it's normally a penny or two we see a ton of option expirations this is also a pretty good indicator of liquidity because if there's no demand for the options they won't offer weeklies they won't offer things like quarterlys the market needs enough people interested in those options in order to make it worthwhile to provide them so the fact that this has so many expirations inherently can start to give you some ideas but most importantly if you pop them open you can see it's a 400 product and again after hours on a 39 delta put it's 4 cents wide very very liquid so absolutely meets that threshold the next one is dividend does it

text: it's the big brother version of iwm and then underlying like i said no underlying now a notable mention here though is it does enjoy section 1256 tax benefits so it essentially mixes your short-term capital gains tax and you actually get a portion of your profits taxed at a long-term capital gains rate so when i'm not trading the covered strangle this is typically my go-to if i'm trading naked short puts naked short calls naked short ratio strangles for that exact reason for it's definitely more efficient you don't have to put on as many contracts and it does have a great tax benefit all right so let's take a look at iwm so as we can see it also has a bunch of weekly expirations not the same number as the spy though so i would argue that the spy is slightly more liquid than iwm you can also see it not slightly actually fairly so because you can also see it in the volume traded now the reason why i didn't bother giving spy an additional check mark although you could argue that it deserves one is from a like pragmatic deployment perspective it really doesn't make a difference they're both extremely liquid products so i don't think that there's truly a discernible outcome if you trade one versus the other via liquidity alone now dividend it also has a dividend that it pays except the russell dividend is 0.67 cents so again it matters just

text: stock again which is why i trade iwm for the coverage strangle and trade iwm very frequently in my core holdings over the rut it's literally because of that because if the rut had shares to trade that paid a dividend that's where i would be especially with that tax benefit but it doesn't so i don't this is why i trade iwm so much and this is why it's one of the largest contributors to my core returns in my portfolio because it really makes a huge difference these small little details when it's deployed over a long period of time so as always any questions or anything let me know hit me up you can find my contact info in the video description below and until next time be an outlier
